div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £ 19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for SUDAN, SUAKIN, direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidan, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yamboas required. and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Council of Ministers.
The Council of Ministers, which was to have been held at Ras-el-Tin Palace to-day, has been postponed until the 31st inst.
Plague.
No cattle plague has been reported during the past week. Four recoveries from bubonic plague are reported from Samaloat and 28 persons remain under treatment.
The First Cataract.
A scheme is said to be on. foot for demanding a concession from the Egyptian Government for the utilisation of the water power of the First Cataract for generating electricity.
Theatre for Alexandria.
The Egyptian Theatrical Company, which is running the Abbas Theatre at Cairo, bas decided to increase its capital to £10.000, and to construct a theatre in masonry at Cairo and another at Alexandria,
All Saints' Churoh, Ramleh.

The committee desire to intimate to members of the congregation that the extraordinary general meeting held last evening at the parish room, Bulkeley, stands adjourned until to-morrow, Friday, 25th inst., at 6.30 p.m.
Agricultural Bank of Egypt.

It is announced that allotment letters for the Three-and-a-Half per cent. Guaranteed bonds can be exchanged for scrip at the office of the London agenoy of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King William-strest, E.C.
Nilometers.

Nilometers are now set up at the following stations in the Southern Sudan: Batiába, Entebbe, Ginga, Kisuma, Mongalla, Gondokore, Wadelai, Bor, Rabeh Shamba, Adwa, Alouf, Attic, Gambela Wan, and Meehra el Rek.
Murderer Caught.

News comes from Maghagha to the effect that Lemloan Bey Saadi, sheikh of the Bedouins, has captured the native vagabond pamed Madi Mohamed, who, not long ago; committed murder and was sentenced to death by default. The murderer is now in Maghagha prison.
The Land Boom.

The Souaya soap manufactory at Karmous, and the Boulangerie Mécanique, which had lost all their capital in unfortunate industrial ventures, are now in a position to make a very fair distribution among the shareholders, thanks to the rise in the, value of land on which their buildings stand.
Cowardly Boatmen.

Two boats on Monday collided in the Kada lia Canal, Gharbieh. The mast cf one fell on the deck of the other, killing two native women and causing very serious injuries to another woman. The native boatmen, in presence of danger, dived into the canal and swam ashore, but they were promptly arrested by the police of Besioun caracol,
College St, Francois-Xavior.

A dramatic performance will be given at the college on Sunday next, on the occasion of the rector's feast day, under the presidency of M. Pierre Girard French Consul-General. The performance, which will commence at 4.30 p.m., will consist of an antique tragedy in two acts and in verse, Les Erinnyes, written by Ch. Leconte de Lisle, the musical portion being by J. Massenet.
The Egyptian Abroad,

At the Guildhall last week, an Egyptian commercial traveller, Alexander Hashin, pleaded guilty to stealing a gold watch from a firm of Regent street jewellers. He was also charged with stealing an overcoat from the billiard room of the Marchester Hotel, Aldersgate street. The manager of this establishment, when the man was caught, administered a thrashing which resulted in Hashin getting two black eyes, braises on the face, and a cut head. Hashin was firat of all committed for trial, but-on his plea of guilty being accepted, was sentenced by Sir Walter Wilkin to four months' imprisonment with hard labour for the theft of the watch. In respect to the goat, the Alderman said that he should have given Hashin an additional four months' had it not been for the punishment wrongly inflicted by the manager of the hotel. He would therefore only give Hashin an additional month, and cautioned the manager as to his conduct in such cases in the future.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Grand Cadi of Egypt has appointed Mohamed Packa Anis director of the Mashhadi Wakfe.

H.E. the Governor of Alexandria will give a dinner at the New Khedivial Hotel next Saturday in honour of Colonel Bird, D.S.O., commanding the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, on the occasion of the latter's appror cbing departure.
Hasran Pacha Assem has been appointed as manager of the Daira of Kasr el-Ali, in succession to Prince Ibrahim Pacha Hilmy, who resigned.
Azz Pacha Izzet leaves a'most direct'y for Athens.
Mansfield Pasha goes home on three months" leave on July 1.
Harvey Pasha has returned to Cairo.

div.head: BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: ARRIVAL OF CAVALRY & ARTILLERY
A HISTORIC REGIMENT.

The Leyland liner (military transport) Cestrian arrived at Alexandria early this morring from Southampton consigned to Mr. N. E. Tamvaco. She brought the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons and U Battery Royal Horse Artillery, which were disembarked during the forenoon and will be despatched to Cairo by special train this afternoon. The disembarkation of the troops, horses, and guns was watched by an interested crowd on Quay 31.
The Inniskillings embarked at Queenstown on the 13th inst., the Cestrian afterwards proceeding to Southampton to embark the Royal Artillery.

The Inniskilling Dragoons, which was never previously in the Land of the Pharaclis, is commanded by Colonel Arthur E. Herbert,, M.V.O., with Major V. S. Sandeman second in command. "It is one of the finest cavalry regiments in the British Army, and one of the most historic. It was raised during the Revolution of 1689 amongst the Protestants of Enniskil'en and the North of Ireland for the defence of that town; and since that period its bistory has been that of the Empire. It bears on its standards the honours of "Inniskilling," "Dettingen," "Waterloo," "Balaklava," "Sevastopol," and "3outh Africa, 1899-1902." Its charge in the Union Brigade at Waterloo, and again at Balaklava, were amorgat the finest achievements of modern war. It went through the Boer War, from start to finish, was constantly in the fighting line, and never had a "regrettable incident." The regimant numbers 15 officers-some are on leave-snd 564 noncommissioned officers and men, with 400 horees. The U Battery Royal Horse Artillery is one of the junior batteries of the "Flying Artillery." It was originally a depot battery, and in 1895 it was converted into a service battery. The battery is one of the two forming the 13th Brigade R.H.A., the other, "T" Battery, being stationed at Umballa, Punjab. U Battery saw a lot of service in the South African War, under the command of Major P. B. Taylor. Its 9-pounders spoke out to some purpose round the kopjes of Paardeberg, and under a heavy shell and rifle fire did splendid work at Driefontein, and again in the capture of the hills round Bloemfontein, they supported the Royal So to Greys. After the occupation of Bloemfontein U Battery was attached to Broadwood's column, which met with a reverse at Sanna's Post. It suffered badly in this actior, being almost wiped out, but was rapidly filled up again, and on the trek. Down to the close it did good service as a battery. At that period a good many of the R. H. A. Batteries were converted in Mounted Rifles for the pursuit of the mobile enemy. After the close of the war, U Battery went home, and was stationed at Manchester, from where it moved to Christ church last year. The officers of the battery are Major and Brevet Lieutenant Colonel H. M. Campbell, commanding; Captain W. R. Elen, D. S. O., Lieutenants D. J. C. E. Sherlock, W. A. Murray, and V.M.C. Napier.

With the arrival of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons and U Battery R. H. A., the troops in Egypt will number a little over 6,000 of all arins. It is intended to keep them at this strength for some time to come.

div.head: THE KHEDIYE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive arrived from Montazsh this morning at Ras el-Tin Palace and granted audiences to the following: Sayed Mahomed Marghani, Sayed Towfik El Bakri, Sayed Abdul Hamid El Bakri; Lord Cromer, who presented Admiral Lambton, in command of the British men-of-war at Port Said; Sir Vincent Corbett; M. Alexandre Max, who presented his nephew, M. Henry Garry; Kaimakam Gillon Bey, and Chevalier Pascaria, Austro-Hungarian Consul, who took leave of his Highness on the occasion of his departure for Kieff.

div.head: DAMIETTA.
div.p: This morning a deputation of the leading inhabitants of Damietta called at the British Agency and the Ministry of the Interior to der and that their town should have a Gonvernorat as in years past. The deputation will await for the return of Lord Cromer to Cairo in order to set before his Lordship the grievances under which the ancient oity of Damietta now groans and which the, inhabitants desire to be reme lied so as to restore the place to some of its erst while prosperity.

div.head: LORD CROMER.
div.p: VISIT TO ALEXANDRIA-
Lord and Lady Cromer arrived at Sidi Gaber from Cairo yesterday evening at 7.25 o'clock and proceeded to San Stefano Hotel.

This morning Lord Cromer went to Ras-el- Tin Palace, and was received in audience by H H. the Khedive. He afterwards visited the Union and British Clubs and the British Consulate, accompanied by Mr. E. B. Gould, I.8.O., British Consul-General. At the British Club Lord Cromer was received and shown round by the hon. secretary and the chairman and members of the committee. His Lordship expressed his entire satisfaction with the appearance of the clab, and wished it all success. He hoped that in the fatore it would be possible for the members to have their meals at the club.
This afternoon, Lord Cromer lays the foundation stone of the new Victoria College at Siouf, Ramleh, at 4.30 p.m.

div.head: FIGHTING IN ARABIA.
div.p: According to reports from Arabia, Abd-el- Aziz ibn Rashid has been succeeded by his nephew, Mutib, who has continued the war against Abd-el-Aziz ibn Saud, who, on his part, is said to be making great preparations to orash the Shammar kingdom of Hail once and for all. Thus far Matib ibn Rashid has had the bast of several engagements with the Wahabis.

div.head: FRANCE AND TURKEY.
div.p: The Tripoli (Africa) correspondent of "Al Bassir" states that the French Government, having made attempts to open up a caravan ronte from Gabes (Tunis) to Wadai via Ghademes Janit, Bilms, and Kanem, and having established a military post at Janit wells, six hours from Ghat, the Tawarek of the district appealed for Turkish aid. Rajeb Paoha, the Governor of Tripoli, sent Lieut. Haj El Senoussi Effendi Sefun to Gawar, south of Fezzan.

Kanem territory has been for the last fire years in the hands of the Senqassi sheikb. A Turkish officer, Abd el Kader Djamali Bey, has been despatched' to Janit and Gawar, on the Kanem road, on a political mission of importance.

div.head: ENGLAND AND EGYPT.
div.p: In a leader on the agreement with Belgiam, "Al Ahram" remarks: "Active as Great Britain has been in the Akaba incident, as in faot the question was one of that country's home problems, what is the cause of the refasal to act in concert with the Egyptian Government, which has to pay? Why did not England ask the opinion of the Legislative Council in a matter that has to do with the interests of Egypt Bat if England believes as occupied by the Akaba affair, England is wrong. The matter is done with, but we Egyptians should like our Government's opinion to be consalted ia affairs of this Bort."

As the negotiations were carried on between Egypt and Turkey until it became clear that the Porte would not abate any of its claims in spite of the remonstrances of the former Government, we cannot see why "Al Ahram" should consider that the Egyptian Government has been in any way neglected.

div.head: "AN APPEAL."
div.p: Dear Sir,-"An Appeal" appeared in your columns dated May 9th over the somewhat cambrous signature of "Motherly love, Relief, and I hope Truth"; it reappeared in a more extended form in your issue of May 21, under the signature of "Brotherly love, Relief and I hope Truth." Your correspondent, who is at the same time, mother and brother to Dr. Albert Edelmann (ths object of the appeal), tells us that the Doctor has been staying with his bi-sexual host for the last two months and adds that he-she has never found the Doctor out in a mistake (in the first letter) nor in a mis-statement (in the second letter) and so hethe believes in him. It would indeed be a orael world if wo were not believed in because we made mistakes. But this is by the way. Dr. Edelmann's mother-brother tells us that he survived a tidal-wave in 1899 and lived to find his way through London to Paris, Palestine, Alexandria and Cairo, where a deeprooted abcess in his leg laid him low in 1901. On his recovery Freemasonry and Mr. Boyle forwarded him at their expense from Cairo to Australia. Here we lose sight of Dr. Edelmann in his mother-brother's letter until his cabaccident in Paris last autumn, after which the Cabdrivers' Association paid his hospital bill and "a society" forwarded him to Egypt. By an esoteric process of reasoning your correspondent qualifies the expression "poor and needy" as applied to Dr. Edelmann because "he has had the grit to travel round the world" at an advanced age and always managed to fall on his fect, excepting, I imagine, in the case of the Paris cab-accident.

Let us hope that, in spite of the Doctor's unfortunate choice of an advocate, "those anxious to exercise that great privilege illustrated by the parable of the Samaritan" (was there ever such a phrase !) will contribute generously to the unqualified poverty and neediness of the good Doctor.-Yours faithfully, Cairo, May 23.
ALFRED LAMBART.

div.head: DEATH OF HENRIK IBSEN.
div.p: A FAMOUS DRAMATIST.
CHRISTIANIA, May 23.
Henrik Ibsen is dead.
(Reuter)
CHRISTIANIA, May 23.
The celebrated author Ibsen is dead.

Ibsen, the most revolutionary figure in the dramatic world in the latter part of the nineteenth centory, has died at the ripe age of close upon 80. His place in the world's literatare is assured, for at a time when the drama bad sunk to an extraordinary state of degradation, he dared to come forward to show an astonished world that the supreme gift of the dramatist is to produce an impression of life which seems, and which is more real than reality. When the Norwegian dramatist appear ed on the scene and ventured to describe men and women as he saw them with the aid of great dramatio intuition and technical talent, the world, still faithful to an utterly superannuated convention in regard to the drama, was taken aback and endeavoured to crush the advocate of an emancipated drama. He was held up as a heartless ironist and a devil's advocate because he did his best and was successful in the presentation of figures who are dramatically "alive." His fame soon spread throughout Europe, and in England and Germany fierce controversies raged in the latter eighties and early nineties over his plays, which made the innermost fibres of many of his hearers' hearts quiver with a feeling which Sardou and his kind were quite anable to evoke. The traditon of what the drama should be had been so obscured that when Ibsen came forward 's works were branded as "problem" plays, as if the treatment of human problems was a novelty instead of being as old 88 cby-

las. Problem was ever at the root of his work. No drama without confl'ct; no conflict without something to decide. All life wortby the name is a problem; and every play that would reproduce life must be either a problem or a platitade. A pepple that is unconscious of having problems to solve, that has outlived its interest in the interpretation of life, is beginning to be at the end of its inte'lectual resources. Senile decay is as surely indicated in a nation as in a man by a dull acquiescence in the immutability of things; and the literature of a waning race is almost always diverted from the great questions of conduct before it expires in mesthetic trivialities. Hence Ibsen's determination to accept problem as the normal material of the drama, and his understanding of drama as "the presentation in parable of the conflict between man's will and his environment," were a pledge at least of vitality in his ideas, and vitality working itself out as creative philo30- phy is the supreme necessity to the art of the atage. Thus Ibsen's name and fame as the dramatic exponent of life in the latter years of the ninetenth century will live long after Sardou, Scribe, and hoc genus omne have been forgotten.
BIOGRAPHICAL DETAILS.

Ibeen was born at Skien, March 20, 1828. He was of German descent on his mother's side, and, spoke German with fluency; but he never wrote anything in that language. He at first studied medicine, but soon abandoned that profession for literatore. Under the pseudonym of Brynjolf Bjarme he pablished in 1850 "Caitlina" (Catiline), a drama in three acts. In the following year be was appointed director of the National Theatre at Bergen and in 1857 want to Christiania as director of the Norske Theatre. The following are the dates of his best-known productions: "Brandt," 1866; "Peer Gynt," 1867; "De Unges Forbund," 1869; "Keiser og Galileeer," 1875; and a volume of poems, "Lyriske Digte," 1871. "The Pillars of Society," 1877, contains, perhaps, the best embodiment of his social philosophy. Other works of his are "Ghost"," 18-1; "A Social Enemy," 1382; "The Wild Dack," 1884; "Rosmersi holm," "The Master Builder," 1892; "Little Eyolf," 1894; "John Gabriel Borkman," 1897, "Love's Comedy," 1900. et.. Ibsen of late years had been the object of a devout oaltas in England, Many of his plays have been translated into English, and his play "Nora o: the Doll's Honse," was produced in 1887 at the Novelty Theatre and again in 1889 at the Olympic, with Miss Achurch in the leading part. Originally published in 1880, it is a pronouncement in dramatic form on much that is now involved in the then so-called "New Woman" question. In Febuary, 1891, "Rosmersholm," "Ghosts," and 'Hedda Gabler," were produced at the Vaadeville in English, and early in 1893 two series of performances of a translation of "The Master Builder" were given by Miss Robins. Ibsen plays were for a time the rage, and, "Hedda Gabler," "Rosmersholm," parts of "Brandt," and "The Enemy of the People," were produced at varions London Theatres. They still are frequently performed in England although of late years Ibsen bad grown to appear rather "old fashioned" since the sudden apotheosis of our dramatic'Whistler, Bernard Shaw.

div.head: ADMIRAL DEWEY FLOATING -DOCK.
div.p: The Cie. Universello du Canal Maritime de

Suez state that the total charges to be received by them for the passage of the Admiral Dewey through the Saez Canal do not amount to £20,000-the sum named by a correspondent in the "Timas" of May 2-but approximately to £6,200, of which only £3,900 is for the transit of the dock itself, the balance of £2,300 being payable on the convoys.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: COMMUNICATION OFFICIELLE
La Commission Munic ale s'est réanie le 23 mai 1906 à 4 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. le Dr. Schiess Pecha.
Mention est faite de l'envoi à tous les membres des procès verbaux de la délégation des 24 avril 1 et 8 mai 1906.

A l'occasion de cette communication et relativement à une autorisation donnée à la Compagnie des Téléphones de se servir de la tranchée ouverte par la Compagnie des Baux dans la route de Ramleh pour y poser s08 cables, M. de Menasce appuyé par plusieurs membres dit que de nombreuses plaintes continaent à se manifester parmi le public au Bujet de la défectuosité du service téléphonique et que la direction de cette Compagnie ne tient aucun compte de ces plaintes et ne songa qu'à augmenter les charges de ses abonnés. Il propose de refuser à l'avenir toute facilité à la Compagnie da genre de belle qui lui a été octroyés tant qu'elle n'aura pas pris des mesures pour satisfaire les voeux da public. Il estime que les infractions de la Société devraient donner lieu à des sanctions et les moyena d'imposer ces sanctions devraient faire l'objet d'une étade da comité da contentieux.
L'Assemblée adopte.
Communication est donnée.

1. d'une lettre da 13 mai 1906 de S. E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant que le Ministère des Finances n'a pas d'objection à ce que la Manioipa'ité soit désormais repré- sentée par deux de ses fonctionnaires au sein de la Commission chargée du recensement et de l'évaluation de la valear locative des biens libres loués,

2. d'une lettre du 2 mai 1906 de 8.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant que le Ministère des Finances n'a pas d'objection en prinpipe au von émis par la Délégation tendant au transfert des échèches de la ville et plus particulièrement de celles du Gabbari dans une zone à réserver a Mex, qai est précisément celle primitivement affectée aux cimetières.

Pour l'étude marie de la question, et pour se rendre compte si le Gouvernement serait disposé à accorder des facilités à la Municipalité pour l'exécution de son projet, le Ministère des finances demande un plan détaillé ainsi qu'un projet d'ensemble de la que3 ti on La Commission prend note que des ordres ont été donnés par la Délégation à l'effet de dresser les plans et projets demandés par le Ministère.

3. d'une lettre da 14 Mai 1906 de S.B. le Ministre de l'Intérieur informant qu'en l'absence en congé de Mr. Williams, l'Inspecteur da 3me Cercle d'Irrigation, Mr. Adamson, Inspecteur intérimaire, le remplacera comme membre de la Commission.
Mention est ensuite donnée de l'envoi à/ tous les membres de l'état précédemment demandé des décisions prises par la Commission dans les cinq dernières années et des saites qui y ont été données.
L'ordre du joar appelle la question de la construction d'une jetée au Port Est demandée par M. W. O. Joseph.
Cette question avait fait l'objet d'études entreprises tant par la Délégation que par les Comités réunis des Finances et des Travaux Pablic.

Le procès verbal relatant l'opinion définitive de ces deux Comités, avait été communiqué préalablement aux membres, et il conclut à l'octroi d'an droit exolasif pour la construction d'ane jetée et de bains an Port Est, dans la zone comprise entre Silsiley et Kail Bey, ce dernier point étant cependant exclu. La concession serait accordée pour 50 ans, après lesquels la jetée et les bains feraient retour à la ville; la Municipalité aurait une participation dans les bénéfices à raison de 50 % après paiement d'on dividende de 8% cumulatif aux aotionnaires. La ville serait représentée au sein da Conseil d'administration; l'exécution serait surveillée par la Municipalité; an délai d'option de six mois serait donné pour la formation de la Société; les travaux devraient être achevés deux ans après la signatare da contrat; les frais d'entretien seraient à la charge du con- cessionnaire; il serait tenn, dans la zone concédée, à constraire des bains à prix réduit pour les pauvres, bains qu'il devra avoir construit au commencement de 1907 pour être utilisés dès l'été de la dite année.

Une discussion s'engage au sujet de cette question, à la suite de laquelle, la Commission par onze voix accepte les conclusions du rapport des Comités des Travaux Publics et finances réunis et accorde la concession de la construction énumérée au dit rapport, mais, en y ajoutant une clause permettant à la Municipalité le rachat de cette soncession à tont moment sur les bases à étudier par la Déléga tion et des Comités des Finances et travaux publics réunis.
Abani Bey trouye qu'il aurait fallu dans la votation trancher tout d'abord la question da monopole laquelle est primordiale et ensuite
voter sur les détails de la concession, an cas où elle serait accordée. Il tient à faire noter qu'une proposition faite par lui dans ce sens n'a pas obtenu la priorité.

Une proposition de la Délégation tendant à la nomination d'un chauffeur mécanicien ponr le service de la pompe automobile, qui serait en même temps chargé d'examiner les chauf feurs d'automobiles en vae de la délivrance d'an certificat d'aptitude est ajournée pour l'étude da point de savoir s'il ne conviendrait pas de nommer un mé anicien de 1er ordre qui serait en même temps chargé de la surveillance des machines routières et autres employées pár la Municipalité.
Sur la proposition de la Dé'égation, les orédits suivants sont approuvés :
1° LB. 120, à titre supplémentaire poun le bornage des terrains des quais, dépense qui sera ensuite remboursée par les acheteurs. 2° L.B. 200, à préleves sur le budget extra-
ordinaire, pour la réparation des routes du quai.
A cette occasion, la Commission charge l'administration de voir s'il n'y a pas opportunité de macadamiser ces routes.
3. L.E. 1450, à prélever sur le produit de la vente des terrains, pour la construction d'an tronçon du collestear Ibrahim depuis le palais de Cristal jusqu'à l'axe de la rae Nabar.
4. L.E. 240, à prélever sur la réserve da budget ordinaire pour l'achat de deux paires de chevaux hongrois pour la brigade des pompiers.
5 LB. 108, à prélever sur la même réserve, pour frais extrajudiciaires :
6 L.E. 60, sur la même réserve, pour. faire face à des augmentations de loyer de kisms sanitaires.

Au sujet de la demande d'an orédit de L.E. 17,000 pour la constraction de la corniche jusqu'à Moustafa Pache, une discussion s'engage, à la suite de laquelle, par 12 voix, la Commission approuve le crédit demandé pour l'exécution de la corniche mais elle estime que la largeur de 15 mètres, trottoirs compris, proposée par les services est insuffisante et qu'il y a lieu de porter cette largeur à 25 mètres.

Cette largeur sera appliquée dès à présent à la partie du parcours de cette route dans les terrains municipaux, saut à voir dans quelle mesure cette largeur pourra être continuée à partir du camp de César sur les terrains privés.

Etant donné que les nouvelles dimensions à donner à la route pourraient se traduire par ane augmentation de dépenses, le crédit ouvert servira à faire face aux frais d'exécution de la roate pour la porter le plus loin possible, sauf à parfaire le crédit par une nouvelle demande en cas d'insuffisance.
La dépense sera prélevée sur le produit de la vente des terrains.

Communication est donnée' da rapport du Comité des Travaux Publics au sujet des modifications au lotissement de certaines parcelles des quais et des évaluation y relatives établies par le Comité d'estimation.

Ls Commission approuve ces modifications. A cette occasion, elle demande au Comité des Travaux Publics de voir si parmi les lots non encore mis en vente dans les quartiers européens, il n'y en aurait pas dont les dimensions pourraient être augmentées.

La Commission adopte divers excédents et emprises, évalués par le conseil d'estimation dans sa séance da 12 mai 1906, et dont état avait été préalablement communiqué aux membres et ratifie une entente agu les Vakfs au sujet da percement de la rue des Pharaons au quartier greo ainsi que les détails de l'é- change avec le Wakf Aboasiri pour l'élargissement de la rue de Ras-el-Tin et la création d'une place au dessus de l'hypogée d'Anfoachy. La séance est levée à 7 h. 45.

div.head: THEATRE ALHAMBRA.
div.p: Hier a eu lieu la seconde représentation de la Geisha qui n'eut pas moins de succès que la première.

La charmante opérette de M. H. Owen Hall et S. Jones à été délicieusement interprétée par toate la troupe. Mme A. Baldi fit une graciease petite Mimosa, douée d'une fort jolie voix; très applaudie dans la romance finale da deuxième acte.

Mlle Leoni tient très bien le rôle de Miss Molly. Ne trouvez-vous point Mlle Leoni que vous levez la jambe, au deuxième acte, an peu plus haut qu'il n'est convenable de le faire à une jeune fille da meilleur monde?, Mme Calligaris, très drôle dans le rôle de Jaliette Diamant nons à démontré une fois de plas que ce que femme veut.........

La place nous manque pour parler de tous les artistes comme nous aurions voulu le faire, nous citerons néanmoins MM. Sacchi dans le rôle de Canningham Carti dans celui de Katana; quand à MM. Urbano et Piraccini, les deux excellents comiques; ils ont soulevé les éclats de rire de toate la
salle.
La Direction, d'autre part, avait fort bien fait les choses et l'action s'est déroulée dans un décor merveilleux; les costumes très fidèles étaient magnifiques.

div.head: MENAGERIE MASSERINI
div.p: C'est vraiment superbe de voir le sang froid et la maestria avec lesquels Monsieur et Ma dame Masserini font travailler leurs peu commodes élèves.

La ménagerie possède un bon nombre d'animaux et c'est un spectacle très recommandable; il a d'ailleurs l'avantage de nous changer un pea de tous les concerts (ai on pent leur donner ca nom) qui étaient jusqu'à présent les seals spectacles d'Alexandrie.

Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny-
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mercredi 23 Mai.

A Londres, hier, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 89 5/8. L'Unifiée a baissé de 1/4 de livre à 104. La National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra ont conservé leurs cours de clôture de la veille. La Delta Light a reperdu 1/8 à 12 1/8. .
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réactionné de 1 franc à 774. La Banque d'Athè nes est demeurée inchangée à 151.
Ici, le marché s'est encore montré, ce matin, réactionnaire et plusieurs valeurs ont payé plas ou moins le petit tribut à cette mauvaise disposition.

Cette tendance persistante à la faible 89 n'a pas de raison d'être spéciale. Auss bien elle est généralement attribuée au chômage déterminé par l'entrée de la morte saison et aussi, à tort on à raison, à l'approche de la liquidation de fin de mois, qui serait dit-on, appelée à se trouver chargée à Alexandrie, sinon au Caire, où la situation est normale et cù les rachats du découvert pourraient ramener une reprise.
La National a fléchi à 26 vendeurs pour olotarer à ce même prix. L'Agricole a faibli à 9 25/32 pour finir à 9 13/16. La Banque d'Orient s'est, par contre, raffermie à 135.
L'action Crédit Foncier est restée à 775 776 et la Daïra à 17 1/16.
La Nile Land a encore perda 1/16 à 14 13/16.

L'action Immobilière a progressé à 366-367. L'action Enterprise and Development est revenue à 11 3/4; la part de fondateur Agricole du Nil à 7 1/2; l'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux à 4; l'action Land Allotment à 3 3/8 7/16 et la part de fondateur à 140; l'action Ciments à 69.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été traités à 15 11/16 l'action ancienne et 14 11/16 la nouvelle; ils ont été poussés en c'ôtore à 15 3/4 et 14 374.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été ramenés à 3 3/4-13/16; les Glymenopoulo à 1 7/16-1/2; les Oasis à 11/32 et les New Egyptian à 27 sh. 9.

Les travaux de construction da railway de la Corporation of Western Egypt, destiné à relier les Oasis.occidentales au réseaux de l'Etat dans la Haute-Egypte, avancent rapidement. D'après les derniers renseignements reçus par la Compagnie, les rails sont déjà posés jusqu'au kilomètre 45, soit environ un tiers de la distance qui sépare la vallée du Nil de l'oasis de Kharga. La voie permanente serait actuellement posée à raison d'an kilomètre par jour; les travaux d'achèvement, qui ont été confiés à un entrepreneur, sont complétés sur un parcours de deux kilomètres depuis la tête de ligne. Un service téléphonique est établi jusqu'au kilomètre 45.

Nous prions instamment les personnes qui ne reçoivent pas régulièrement notre Circulaire de nous aviser sans retard, afin que nous puissions prendre des mesures immédiates pour assurer la ponctualité du service d'expédition.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Société des Excelsior Hotels sont informés que, par décision du conseil d'administration et aux termes des Statuts, le versement du second quart, soit L.E. 1 par action, est appelé à partir du 1er jain prochain jusqu'au 15 da même mois au plus tard, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire ou à Alexdrie, qui en délivrera quittanca valable sur le certificat provisoire, en lien et place des deux administrateurs de la Société.
Rappelons que l'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Hamburg and American Line Co. a liea après demain,an Grand Continental Hotel, $5 h. 30 p.m.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Nungovich Hotels Co. est fixée à samedi prochain, 4 h. p.m., au Grand Continental Hotel.
Les cours du coton en Amérique sont arrivés en reprise. Hier, le Juillet a gagné 6 points et l'octobre 7. Le disponible est resté invarié à son cours précédent.
Les arrivages à New York ont été de 17,000 balles contre 23,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est en petite réaction.
Ici, le Juillet, qui a fini hier soir très faible
à 20 17/32 sur des ventes forcées de la spéculation et l'absence d'acheteurs, a ouvert ce matin à 20 5/8 pour olurer à 20 3/4.
D'après un câblogramme de New-York en date d'hier, un incendie a détrait 20,000 balles de coton.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, May 17.

Only a moderate busile-s has been done in Eyptian Cotton this week; the quotations of Brown being unchanged, while Fair Upper is 5/16d. and Good Fair 1/3d per lb. lower. In Futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the latest quotations:-

May 10.21d Aug. 9.59. Aug. 9.59 Nov. 8.53 June 10.11. Sapt. 9.51 Dec. 8.43 July 10.1 Oct. 9.31 Jan. 8.29 American Futures.-The Market this week has been somewhat more active, and prices for the Old Crop positions are 6 points higher, whilst New Crops are generally 3 points below those of last Thursday. The advance is chiefly due to increased takings by spinners, in addition to which there have been considerable lines purchased for export. The accounts of the New Crop are causing anxiety: there is a growing impression that the weather conditions are not favourable, and that the increase in the acreage is less than had generally been anticipated. It is, of course, early days for any decided opinion about a crop which is still being planted, but manipulation is naturally working upon these fears and is also probably exaggerating the supply that is considered necessary for the consump tion of the world next season, on account of the great 'buoyancy of trade of this and last season.
The latest values are, delivery:
May 6.05d Aug/Sept 5.97 Dec/Jan. 5.78 May/June 6.05 Sept./Oct 5.84 Jan./Feb. 5.76 June/July 6.05 Oot./Nov 5.77 Feb./Mar. 5.77 July/Aug. 6.05 Nov./Dec. 5.76 Mar./Apl. 5.78

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et des Télégraphes de l'Etat à l'honneur de porter àla connaissance da publie qu'à partir da 25 mai courant, un Bureau Télégraphique sera ouvert à Khanka pour l'échange des correspondances en langues Baropéennes et Arabes.
L'horaire d'ouverture de ce Bureau sera de 8 b. a.m. à 5 h. p.m.
Le Caire, le 23 Mai 1906.
AVIS
L'Administration des Chemins de fer et des Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance da pablio que le Baresa Télé- graphique de Mallaha sera fermé à partir da
25 mi courant.
Jaire, le 28 Mai 1906.
